contain_file_line('/etc/libvirt/libvirtd.conf listen_tls').with(:line => "listen_tls = 0") } it { is_expected.to contain_file_line('/etc/libvirt/libvirtd.conf listen_tcp').with(:line => "listen_tcp = contain_nova_config('libvirt/live_migration_uri').with_value('qemu+ssh://foobar@%s/system')} it { is_expected.to contain_file_line('/etc/libvirt/libvirtd.conf listen_tls').with(:line => "listen_tls = contain_nova_config('libvirt/live_migration_uri').with_value('qemu+ssh://%s/system?foo=%%25&bar=baz')} it { is_expected.to contain_file_line('/etc/libvirt/libvirtd.conf listen_tls').with(:line => commit_message:
Guard calls which won't work from within containers

Ensure that calls to setup live migration are not made if
the charm is running from inside a LXD container, as the
calls will fail (config needs to be done on the host, not
from within the container).

Change-Id: I1633ba0ef5030b4d170bcea9d0c90a781863b168
Closes-Bug: 1633633
(cherry picked from commit 8a7e9753c5c6c20d90ce15d84e9c54da63d39244)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-lxd refs/changes/04/452404/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not is_container(): # NOTE(jamespage): None of the below is worth doing when running # within a container on an all-in-one install # Configure live migration if ubuntu_release == 'xenial': apt_install('linux-image-extra-%s' % os.uname()[2], fatal=True) if ubuntu_release >= 'xenial': modprobe('netlink_diag') # Enable/disable use of ext4 within nova-lxd containers if os.path.exists(EXT4_USERNS_MOUNTS): with open(EXT4_USERNS_MOUNTS, 'w') as userns_mounts: userns_mounts.write( 'Y\n' if config('enable-ext4-userns') else 'N\n' )

Change-Id: I8b47a23e94de8676c415a66da2097fc69ceb8336
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-31 15:22:45.000000000', 'files': ['zun/tests/contrib/gate_hook.sh', 'devstack/settings'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zun/commit/b48df2f5bbb203b784184dc7ed8ca552433c9fb9', 'message': "Enable WSGI mode in gate only

In before, zun devstack plugin enabled wsgi mode by default. This
patch proposed the reverse: disable wsgi mode by default. This fall
back to the screen mode if users haven't explicitly set
ZUN_USE_MOD_WSGI to True. However, we enable wsgi mode in gate to
satisfy the requirement of community wsgi goal [1].

The rational of this change is to ease the development process by
running zun-api at screen, which is more dev-friendly than running
it in apache2/httpd. In screen, it is easier to do dev operations
like shutdown/restart/debug.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/pike/
    deploy-api-in-wsgi.html

Change-Id: I8b47a23e94de8676c415a66da2097fc69ceb8336
"}]
commit_message:
Enable WSGI mode in gate only

In before, zun devstack plugin enabled wsgi mode by default. This
patch proposed the reverse: disable wsgi mode by default. This fall
back to the screen mode if users haven't explicitly set
ZUN_USE_MOD_WSGI to True. However, we enable wsgi mode in gate to
satisfy the requirement of community wsgi goal [1].

The rational of this change is to ease the development process by
running zun-api at screen, which is more dev-friendly than running
it in apache2/httpd. In screen, it is easier to do dev operations
like shutdown/restart/debug.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/pike/
    deploy-api-in-wsgi.html

Change-Id: I8b47a23e94de8676c415a66da2097fc69ceb8336

commit_message:
monasca-notification: various fixes

* Add missing rcopenstack-monasca-notification symlink
  on SUSE
* Fix permissions
* Fixed duplicated creation of /var/log/monasca-notification
* Use an invalid email address in example configuration (rather
  than a hp.com one).

Change-Id: Ied80ea4d520fc9a78c68dc84dd81d9fce332b233
(cherry picked from commit 4bee2e9cefb475a4c04ead61db643e29684edc50)

commit_message:
Uses _compat_conn where WMI objects need to be updated or added

This patch only affects Windows / Hyper-V Server 2012.

On Windows / Hyper-V Server 2012_compat_conn represents the old WMI
connection, in order to ensure that the add / update operations work
properly, since PyMI's and WMI's GetText_(1) outputs are different,
causing an issue on 2012.

Closes-Bug: #1678968

Change-Id: I5542046375114c24387cbcfba0aa8528f8e0dd6d

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary tearDown function in testcase

In testcase, tearDown will be called automatically. This patch used to
 remove tearDown functions that do nothing. Besides, it will keep code clean.

Change-Id: Ib17fa195b77eb1e71a16c83ea270781bcaf0162e

commit_message:
Add check for idempotent id in tempest tests

Idempotent id for tempest tests must be unique, as it's used to
trace tests even in the event of refactors. This patch adds a new
check using check-uuid tool from tempest to validate id uniqueness.

Change-Id: I415699d2349ee0c4becfb404c60a06f244f78ba0

added_lines: from manilaclient import client as manila_clientdef get_manila_client_from_env(): # We should catch KeyError exception with the purpose of # source or configure openrc file. auth_url = os.environ['OS_AUTH_URL'] username = os.environ['OS_USERNAME'] password = os.environ['OS_PASSWORD'] project_name = os.environ['OS_PROJECT_NAME'] # Either project(user)_domain_name or project(user)_domain_id # would be acceptable. project_domain_name = os.environ.get("OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME") project_domain_id = os.environ.get("OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID") user_domain_name = os.environ.get("OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME") user_domain_id = os.environ.get("OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID") auth = identity.Password(auth_url=auth_url, username=username, password=password, project_name=project_name, project_domain_id=project_domain_id, project_domain_name=project_domain_name, user_domain_id=user_domain_id, user_domain_name=user_domain_name) session = ks.Session(auth=auth) return manila_client.Client(session=session, client_version='2') def get_manila_client_from_creds(): auth_plugin, session = _get_cloud_config_auth_data() return manila_client.Client(session=session, auth=auth_plugin, client_version='2') self.manila_client = get_manila_client_from_env() self.manila_client = get_manila_client_from_creds()

There are to parameter for ceph-mon/ceph-osd/radosgw, "-f" and "-d".

    -d run in foreground, log to stderr.
    -f run in foreground, log to usual location.

When log tin stderr, docker engine will collect the logs. It is useless
and we should write the log into file only. Then stop writing log to
stderr.

ceph-mon log location is controlled by "mon cluster log file".

Change-Id: I7883a4316420bc2bf4c772cb7248b663359f54b7
Closes-Bug: #1677237
(cherry picked from commit 2947a95c291c0ddfbf60cd611f30f2ece6173098)

commit_message:
Fix ceph log location

There are to parameter for ceph-mon/ceph-osd/radosgw, "-f" and "-d".

    -d run in foreground, log to stderr.
    -f run in foreground, log to usual location.

When log tin stderr, docker engine will collect the logs. It is useless
and we should write the log into file only. Then stop writing log to
stderr.

ceph-mon log location is controlled by "mon cluster log file".

Change-Id: I7883a4316420bc2bf4c772cb7248b663359f54b7
Closes-Bug: #1677237
(cherry picked from commit 2947a95c291c0ddfbf60cd611f30f2ece6173098)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/23/453023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set auth flag so ceilometer auth is enabled

Ceilometer Auth should be enabled even if ceilometer api
is not. Lets decouple these, this flag will be used in
puppet-tripleo where ceilometer::keystone::auth class
is initialized.

Change-Id: Iffebd40752eafb1d30b5962da8b5624fb9df7d48
Closes-bug: #1677354
(cherry picked from commit 0d04302abd19f98df3cd700f9cc4ec47273e5dac)

subject: Fixes crash when starting Neutron OVS Agent on Windows
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-06 16:09:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f3d6bb21b27ca6ef44d9d674d5564c42a1712f55', 'message': 'Fixes crash when starting Neutron OVS Agent on Windows

The neutron OVS Agent does not start on Windows because
of Linux specific import.

The fix consists in moving the method get_ip_version in
the common module of ip_lib being the only one used from
the module. We will import the common module
agent/common/ip_lib after that.

Change-Id: I95e9a6fa99e0992499f46a4f0debccd47b8a936c
Closes-Bug: #1670402
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-07 13:20:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/84ae342cd45641d6244275e17bb86b38370b4abc', 'message': 'Fixes crash when starting Neutron OVS Agent on Windows

The neutron OVS Agent does not start on Windows because
of Linux specific import.

The fix consists in moving the method get_ip_version in
the common module of ip_lib being the only one used from
the module. We will import the common module
agent/common/ip_lib after that.

commit_message:
Fixes crash when starting Neutron OVS Agent on Windows

The neutron OVS Agent does not start on Windows because
of Linux specific import.

The fix consists in moving the method get_ip_version in
the common module of ip_lib being the only one used from
the module. We will import the common module
agent/common/ip_lib after that.

Change-Id: I95e9a6fa99e0992499f46a4f0debccd47b8a936c
Closes-Bug: #1670402
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/11/442011/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import netaddr def get_ip_version(ip_or_cidr): return netaddr.IPNetwork(ip_or_cidr).version

commit_message:
Use HostAddressOpt for opts that accept IP and hostnames

Some configuration options were accepting both IP addresses
and hostnames. Since there was no specific OSLO opt type to
support this, we were using ``StrOpt``. The change [1] that
added support for ``HostAddressOpt`` type was merged in Ocata
and became available for use with oslo version 3.22.

This patch changes the opt type of configuration options to use
this more relevant opt type - HostAddressOpt.

[1] I77bdb64b7e6e56ce761d76696bc4448a9bd325eb

Change-Id: I66fb2097a4b6908fc6ee9f41ff141d3067a18a31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuxi refs/changes/47/450547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.HostAddressOpt('my_ip', help=_('IP address of this machine.')),
deleted_lines: cfg.StrOpt('my_ip', help=_('IP address of this machine.')),

unused:

astroid, oslo.utils, oslo.i18n, oslo.log, oslo.config, six

commit_message:
Add console tab into details view

This patch adds console tab into details view. Console view
gets console_url using attach method and access from browser
via websocket using console_url.

Change-Id: I273e83eb114e93371a23b9a1e9d26ceacb6b71d5
Implements: blueprint interactive-mode
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun-ui refs/changes/70/445870/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from django.views import generic from horizon import exceptions from zun_ui.api import client class SerialConsoleView(generic.TemplateView): template_name = 'project/container/containers/console.html' def get_context_data(self, **kwargs): context = super(SerialConsoleView, self).get_context_data(**kwargs) context['container_id'] = self.kwargs['container_id'] try: console_url = client.container_attach(self.request, self.kwargs['container_id']) context["console_url"] = console_url except exceptions.NotAvailable: context["error_message"] = _( "Cannot get console for container %s.") % self.kwargs[ 'container_id'] return context

Currently when we do rebuild/resize/migrate/live-migration/
shelved/unshelved on an instance, if the parallel API operations
happen on the same instance, like: attaching/detaching volume
and network, as a result these operations such as rebuild
interact with volume/interface operations in an undefined way,
in most case that cause the instance ERROR.

This specification purpose to check the conflicting operations
in API layer, avoid these conflicting operations to execute in
parallel.

APIImpact

commit_message:
Add device updating task status

Currently when we attach/detach volume and network
interface from instance, the task state of the instance
is unchanged, it cause some issues.

This specification purpose to add one new task state
"device_updating" into the instance life cycle.

APIImpact

blueprint task-states-improvement

Co-Authored-By: Kevin_Zheng <zhengzhenyu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: Ie53c71373269ffe732866da4e6cce7ded3a7b234
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/78/216578/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================================== Improve task states for attaching/detaching volume and network interface ======================================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/task-states-improvement Adds 4 task states (attaching_volume, detaching_volume, attaching_interface, detaching_interface) into the instance life cycle. Problem description =================== Currently when we attach/detach volume and network interface from instance, the task state of the instance is unchanged, it cause some issues. 1. The users have on idea about what's happening on the instance when attaching/detaching volume and network interface. 2. In some API concurrent requests scenarios the operation results are unpredictable and inconclusive, for example: do the concurrent operation rebuilding-instance and attaching-volume for the instance. Use Cases --------- 1. End users attach/detach volume and network interface to instance, they can know which operation is in progress according to task state of the instance. 2. In API concurrent requests scenarios, some API requests will be denied, because another operation is underway, these API operations can't be executed at the same time. The end users should be notified by raising some exceptions from API, let them know they are doing some wrong things, it might cause unpredictable and inconclusive result, like: do the concurrent operation rebuilding-instance and attaching-volume for the instance Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== Adds 4 task states (attaching_volume, detaching_volume, attaching_interface, detaching_interface) into the instance life cycle. Set the instance.task_state as 'attaching_volume' in compute/api.py and assert the current task_state is None when we attach a volume to the instance, like this:: instance.task_state = task_states.ATTACHING_VOLUME instance.save(expected_task_state=[None]) Then update the instance.task_state as None when the attaching-volume workflow success in compute/manager.py, like this:: instance.task_state = None instance.save(expected_task_state=task_states.ATTACHING_VOLUME) If the attaching-volume failed, revert instance.task_state to None by using the decorator @reverts_task_state. Detaching volume and attaching/detaching network interface workflow are same as attaching volume, the instance.task_state will be updated to related state. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Four new task states will be exported to end users, and python-novaclient don't need to be modified. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Rui Chen <chenrui.momo@gmail.com> Work Items ---------- 1. Adds 4 new task_state into task_states.py (attaching_volume, detaching_volume, attaching_interface, detaching_interface) 2. Update the instance.task_state to related value at the beginning of attach/detach operation method in compute/api.py. 3. Update the instance.task_state to None when these operations success in compute/manager.py 4. Adds the decorator @reverts_task_state on the attach/detach_* methods. 5. Update the related unit testes and add some new test cases to cover the new logic. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= The related unit and function test cases will be added and updated. Documentation Impact ==================== The new task states should be introduced in related documentation. References ========== None History ======= None

commit_message:
Fix the check of docker installation

In before, we checked docker installation by:

  $ rpm -q docker-engine

However, this doesn't work for all cases in fedora 24.
* If docker was installed by "sudo dnf install docker-engine", the
  package will be named as "docker". Therefore, it should be checked
  by "rpm -q docker".
* If docker was installed by devstack (by using
  https://get.docker.com/), the package will be named as
  "docker-engine". Therefore, it should be checked by
  "rpm -q docker-engine".

This commit added check for "docker" as well.

Change-Id: If2fc8a9d210bb663bfd9780c564053a901327a20
Closes-Bug: #1647459

commit_message:
Modify PCI without numa node info treatment

Modify those PCI devices without numa node info treatment
when launch an instance with some requirements of NUMA and
PCI resources.

Change-Id: I187f5e9fb47e2ec937964ee3729324bb5f6c1a52
Implements: blueprint Modify-PCI-without-numa-node-info-treatment
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/19/334419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Modify PCI without numa node info treatment =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/modify-pci-without-numa-node-info-treatment Modify those PCI devices without numa node info treatment when launch an instance with some requirements of NUMA and PCI resources. Problem description =================== Currently, if some compute nodes don't report numa node info for pci devices, then these pci devices will be regarded as "belong to all numa node" to deal with by default. It can lead to a problem that pci devices are not on the numa node which CPU\MEM on. In this way, the real purpose of I/O (PCIe) Based NUMA Scheduling is not reached. More serious is that the user will be wrong thought pci devices is on the numa node that CPU\MEM on. Use Cases --------- Sometimes, there are some compute nodes don't report numa node info for pci devices. Administrator want to boot a VM with SR-IOV in NUMA envirment, and they want the pci devices must on the numa node that instance's MEM\CPU on. Proposed change =============== Currently,these pci devices will be regarded as "belong to all numa node" to deal with by default. We need to modify those PCI devices without numa node info treatment when launch an instance with some requirements of NUMA and PCI resources. In this case, we need "ignore these PCI devices". If we consider the BP https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/share-pci-device-between-numa-nodes which in discussing, Then the proposed change will be: If we share pci devices between numa nodes, these pci devices will be keep regarded as "belong to all numa node" in above case. If we don't share pci devices between numa nodes. these pci devices will be regarded as "be ignored" in above case. Alternatives ------------ Method _filter_pools_for_numa_cells in nova/pci/stats.py will be change, when we filter these numa cells for pci devices, we need remove the numa cell which cell id equal null. Data model impact ----------------- There will be no change to the Data model impact. REST API impact --------------- There will be no change to the REST API. Security impact --------------- This blueprint does not introduce any new security issues. Notifications impact -------------------- This blueprint does not introduce new notifications. Other end user impact --------------------- This blueprint adds no other end user impact. Other deployer impact --------------------- Pci devices without numa_node info will be ignore when launch an instance with some requirements of NUMA and PCI resources. Developer impact ---------------- This blueprint will have no developer impact. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Jinquan Ni <ni.jinquan@zte.com.cn> Work Items ---------- * Modify _filter_pools_for_numa_cells in nova/pci/stats.py Testing ======= Unit tests will be added to validate these modifications. Documentation Impact ==================== This feature will not add a new scheduling filter, but We will add documentation as required. References ========== None

commit_message:
Resume Guests State upgrade

blueprint: resume-guests-state-upgrade
Change-Id: I453975caa54bf62e7e1d62c8b6a377a67ee1358d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/88/375388/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Recover instance from database data on error at resume guests state ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/resume-guests-state-upgrade It works properly if the compute host reboot does not changed anything with the environment of the instance, e.g. libvirt definition, availablity of the instance local disk. We would like to improve the robustness of the resume guest state feature by handling these edge cases. The evacuate command needs human interaction, but the resume guests state would trying to automatically fix the instance in the described cases. If resume_guests_state is finished and the instance is still broken, the system administrator still could fix it by evacuation. Problem description =================== If we get any error during resume guests state, then nova automatically sets the state of the instance to error and does not try to recover it. Thereafter the instance can't be rebuilt or started anymore. We can only delete it, but there is a chance that rebuilding the instance or the libvirt definition restore would solve this problem. Use Cases --------- Main use cases is when resume_guests_state flag is set to True and we get some error during resume, like: * Physical data is missing from the disk * Libvirt definition is missing from the host * Other type of error due to some failure Proposed change =============== * Rebuild instance in case of a replaced hardware (e.g.: due to disk failure) and local instance files are disappeared and instance definition from libvirt is missing. * Restore definition into libvirt in case of a replaced hardware, when instance definition from libvirt is missing, but instance files are not disappeared, because they were stored on a shared storage. * Set instance state to error, if the problem is of other nature We should implement as more bit milestones: * At first we need implement the automatic rebuild with any new config flag. * Next time we should detect the accurate error reason, then implement the solutions. If we are done, should remove the introduced config flag. Alternatives ------------ We introduce a new flag (e.g.: resume_guests_state_rebuild_on_error), which if True, then nova automatically tries to rebuild the instance no matter what type of error happened, but only when getting the error during resume. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- We try to minimized data security impact, but there is a chance to data loss. On rebuild we lose all the data from an instance, but if we use shared storage and we store data on this, then persistent data will be kept. If we need only to restore definition into libvirt, we don’t have any security risks. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- xavvior Work Items ---------- * Modify the manager.py, that the automatic rebuild on error start. * Introduce a new config flag, wherewith we can turn on this feature. * Detect the source of the error and investigate the cases. * In case instance missing from the disk, than we trying to rebuild this. * In case instance is available, but from the libvirt missing the instance definition, then we restore the restore the libvirt definition and trying to start. * In case other, behave as originally: set instance state to error. * Remove the introduced config flag and became default the new solution. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= We need to supplement the old resume guests state unit tests with new cases. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1585494 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/322341/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/343542/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/347256/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/349582/ http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2016/nova.2016-09-01-21.00.log.html History ======= None

commit_message:
Clearing memory will be needed after deleting vm

We can analyze content in memory which is used by VM. If memory
is not cleared after deleting VM, this will cause a safety problem.
So we need VM's memoryclear function, memory used by VM will be
cleared to zero if memoryclear function is configured when creating
VM. And this will solve a safety problem of using VM.

Change-Id: I06e1968664cd5a2ef11861f770c8101238589ec1
Implements: blueprint clearing-memory-after-deleting-vm

Problem description =================== We can analyze content of memory used by vm if memory is not cleared after deleting vm, this will cause a safety problem. Use Cases --------- Memory used by vm will be cleared to zero if clearing memory function is configured when creating VM. Proposed change =============== Add memoryclear to memoryBacking section of vm's xml if hw:memoryclear in flavor or hw_memoryclear in image is set to True. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- No schema change is needed. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- We can analyze content of memory used by vm if memory is not cleared after deleting vm, this will cause a safety problem. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- None Work Items ---------- Add memoryclear to memoryBacking section of vm's xml if hw:memoryclear in flavor or hw_memoryclear in image is set to True. <memoryBacking> <memoryclear/> </memoryBacking> Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test coverage will be provided. New tempest test case will be provided that will try to boot a vm with hw:memoryclear = True in flavor used by vm. The vm should be successful and its xml should include <memoryclear/>. commit_message:
libvirt: Time synchronization with qemu guest agent when resuming VM

VM's clock always loses time when resuming from paused state, because
guest OS can't aware pausing/resuming so its clock continues
from the moment it was suspended.

This specification proposes nova-compute libvirt driver should
invoke virDomainSetTime API to adjust guest time with hardware
clock when resuming VM.

Blueprint: time-sync-with-qemu-guest-agent-when-resuming-vm

Change-Id: I160c9469795ff73d89a251898c7d9390ad0b0e59
Singed-off-by: Taku Izumi <izumi.taku@jp.fujitsu.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/25/347625/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Time synchronization with qemu guest agent when resuming VM ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/time-sync-with-qemu-guest-agent-when-resuming-vm Problem description =================== VM's clock always loses time when resuming from paused state, because guest OS can't aware pausing/resuming so its clock continues from the moment it was suspended. The common practice to deal with this problem is to run NTP client on VM. However this solution is not perfect, because NTP can't fix time in case the time shift is too big. Use Cases --------- Deployers take use of this feature to avoid the wrong time on resumed VM instances Proposed change =============== nova-compute libvirt driver will invoke virDomainSetTime API against KVM instances with QEMU Guest agent installed in order to adjust guest time with hardware clock when resuming VM instance on condition that both 'hw_qemu_guest_agent' and 'sync_time_on_resume' property in the image medata are set to yes. The prerequisites of this feature are: 1. the hypervisor is 'qemu' or 'kvm' 2. libvirt >=1.2.5 (virDomainSetTime API supported) is installed in the hypervisor 3. QEMU Guest Agent is installed and enabled in the instance 4. Both 'hw_qemu_guest_agent' and 'sync_time_on_resume' property in the image metadata are set to 'yes' Alternatives ------------ Run NTP client on VM or End users manually set time by themself after resuming from pause state. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: izumi777 Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- Impelemt automatic time synchronization when resuming VM. Patchset of this feature will be small one, so we don't have to break this feature. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= It is good to extend existing "Suspend/Resume an instance" scenario test. "Suspend, Sleep, Resume, and check guest time" scenario should be added. Documentation Impact ==================== Need to document how to use this feature in OpenStack Operations Guide References ========== None History ======= None

commit_message:
Add ability to get device by mac_address

switch_info key in local_link_information is optional, and ironic-inspector
doesn't set this field by default. Whith this patch it is possible to
pick device based on 'switch_id' key. For this device in ngs config must
have option 'ngs_mac_address' set. If 'switch_id' is set it will take
precedence over switch_info.

Change-Id: I0a03501701d2fd199af1df570e36a6d2a9df1250

commit_message:
Add NetworkDriver api AllocateNetwork and FreeNetwork

Kuryr-libentwork missed AllocateNetwork and FreeNetwork.
This two apis also missed in libnetwork document:
https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/issues/1699

Change-Id: Ic84ecb65ed9b801c70e90d519965e1316ac4ca72
Closes-Bug: #1677299
Partially-Implements: BP docker-v2plugin

added_lines: @app.route('/NetworkDriver.AllocateNetwork', methods=['POST']) def network_driver_allocate_network(): """Allocate new network. Libnetwork miss this api in their doc. https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/issues/1699 See the following like for more detail about the spec: https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/blob/master/driverapi/driverapi.go """ LOG.debug("Received /NetworkDriver.AllocateNetwork") return flask.jsonify(const.SCHEMA['SUCCESS']) @app.route('/NetworkDriver.FreeNetwork', methods=['POST']) def network_driver_free_network(): """Free new network. Libnetwork miss this api in their doc. https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/issues/1699 See the following like for more detail about the spec: https://github.com/docker/libnetwork/blob/master/driverapi/driverapi.go """ LOG.debug("Received /NetworkDriver.FreeNetwork") return flask.jsonify(const.SCHEMA['SUCCESS'])

commit_message:
Spec for supporting authentication methods based on image metadata

Nova should be able to accept or reject 'create' or 'recreate' API
calls, and respond with the appropriate HTTP response code, based on
image metadata and data supplied with the request.

Co-Authored-By: Aline Bousquet <albousque@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I4b4f19609d85c2a1aa40d45c6a54bf0cea64781a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/73/326073/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================================== Support Authentication Methods Based on Image Metadata ====================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/auth-based-on-image-metadata Operating system images are not homogeneous - they support different authentication methods depending on OS type, included software, configuration, etc. An image provider, such as Glance, can publish image meta-data which describes the authentication types supported for a particular image. It would be very useful if nova could determine at 'nova boot' time whether enough information has been provided by the request in order to setup one or more remote authentication methods for the requester. Problem description =================== Imagine you want to provision a new instance through Nova. You invoke 'nova boot', passing various options, including the UUID of an image which only supports SSH keypair based remote login. However, you neglect to provide the necessary public key to the 'nova boot' call. Today, nova will gladly boot the instance, even if there's no way for the requester to access the machine. This specification aims to solve that problem. The implementation of this specification should give Nova the ability to understand enough image metadata, based on administrator configuration, to reject 'create' or 'recreate' calls which do not include enough information to allow the requester to remotely login to the provisioned instance. Use Cases --------- An end user should get feedback immediately if they try to boot an instance to which they will have no remote access. Otherwise, computing resources are consumed and it will take time for the end user to realize their mistake. Deployers will need to decorate images with available authentication methods and configure Nova to recognize the conditions needed to be met for each method. Proposed change =============== Create a Nova configuration option ``validate_authentication_methods`` which enables or disables this feature completely. Make Nova check supported authentication methods of the image against supplied credentials before sending an HTTP response to ``create`` or ``recreate`` calls. This would require a query to the image provider to get image metadata, or intelligently caching image metadata (which is unlikely to change with great frequency) before the HTTP response is sent. Posting this to get preliminary feedback on the scope of this spec. **CHANGES STOP HERE** Alternatives ------------ What other ways could we do this thing? Why aren't we using those? This doesn't have to be a full literature review, but it should demonstrate that thought has been put into why the proposed solution is an appropriate one. Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change. * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated, for example if you need to take into account existing instances, or modify other existing data describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- Each API method which is either added or changed should have the following * Specification for the method * A description of what the method does suitable for use in user documentation * Method type (POST/PUT/GET/DELETE) * Normal http response code(s) * Expected error http response code(s) * A description for each possible error code should be included describing semantic errors which can cause it such as inconsistent parameters supplied to the method, or when an instance is not in an appropriate state for the request to succeed. Errors caused by syntactic problems covered by the JSON schema definition do not need to be included. * URL for the resource * URL should not include underscores, and use hyphens instead. * Parameters which can be passed via the url * JSON schema definition for the request body data if allowed * Field names should use snake_case style, not CamelCase or MixedCase style. * JSON schema definition for the response body data if any * Field names should use snake_case style, not CamelCase or MixedCase style. * Example use case including typical API samples for both data supplied by the caller and the response * Discuss any policy changes, and discuss what things a deployer needs to think about when defining their policy. Example JSON schema definitions can be found in the Nova tree http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas Note that the schema should be defined as restrictively as possible. Parameters which are required should be marked as such and only under exceptional circumstances should additional parameters which are not defined in the schema be permitted (eg additionaProperties should be False). Reuse of existing predefined parameter types such as regexps for passwords and user defined names is highly encouraged. Security impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. For more detailed guidance, please see the OpenStack Security Guidelines as a reference (https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Security/Guidelines). These guidelines are a work in progress and are designed to help you identify security best practices. For further information, feel free to reach out to the OpenStack Security Group at openstack-security@lists.openstack.org. Notifications impact -------------------- Please specify any changes to notifications. Be that an extra notification, changes to an existing notification, or removing a notification. Other end user impact --------------------- Aside from the API, are there other ways a user will interact with this feature? * Does this change have an impact on python-novaclient? What does the user interface there look like? Performance Impact ------------------ Describe any potential performance impact on the system, for example how often will new code be called, and is there a major change to the calling pattern of existing code. Examples of things to consider here include: * A periodic task might look like a small addition but if it calls conductor or another service the load is multiplied by the number of nodes in the system. * Scheduler filters get called once per host for every instance being created, so any latency they introduce is linear with the size of the system. * A small change in a utility function or a commonly used decorator can have a large impacts on performance. * Calls which result in a database queries (whether direct or via conductor) can have a profound impact on performance when called in critical sections of the code. * Will the change include any locking, and if so what considerations are there on holding the lock? Other deployer impact --------------------- Discuss things that will affect how you deploy and configure OpenStack that have not already been mentioned, such as: * What config options are being added? Should they be more generic than proposed (for example a flag that other hypervisor drivers might want to implement as well)? Are the default values ones which will work well in real deployments? * Is this a change that takes immediate effect after its merged, or is it something that has to be explicitly enabled? * If this change is a new binary, how would it be deployed? * Please state anything that those doing continuous deployment, or those upgrading from the previous release, need to be aware of. Also describe any plans to deprecate configuration values or features. For example, if we change the directory name that instances are stored in, how do we handle instance directories created before the change landed? Do we move them? Do we have a special case in the code? Do we assume that the operator will recreate all the instances in their cloud? Developer impact ---------------- Discuss things that will affect other developers working on OpenStack, such as: * If the blueprint proposes a change to the driver API, discussion of how other hypervisors would implement the feature is required. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: <launchpad-id or None> Other contributors: <launchpad-id or None> Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ * Include specific references to specs and/or blueprints in nova, or in other projects, that this one either depends on or is related to. * If this requires functionality of another project that is not currently used by Nova (such as the glance v2 API when we previously only required v1), document that fact. * Does this feature require any new library dependencies or code otherwise not included in OpenStack? Or does it depend on a specific version of library? Testing ======= Please discuss the important scenarios needed to test here, as well as specific edge cases we should be ensuring work correctly. For each scenario please specify if this requires specialized hardware, a full openstack environment, or can be simulated inside the Nova tree. Please discuss how the change will be tested. We especially want to know what tempest tests will be added. It is assumed that unit test coverage will be added so that doesn't need to be mentioned explicitly, but discussion of why you think unit tests are sufficient and we don't need to add more tempest tests would need to be included. Is this untestable in gate given current limitations (specific hardware / software configurations available)? If so, are there mitigation plans (3rd party testing, gate enhancements, etc). Documentation Impact ==================== Which audiences are affected most by this change, and which documentation titles on docs.openstack.org should be updated because of this change? Don't repeat details discussed above, but reference them here in the context of documentation for multiple audiences. For example, the Operations Guide targets cloud operators, and the End User Guide would need to be updated if the change offers a new feature available through the CLI or dashboard. If a config option changes or is deprecated, note here that the documentation needs to be updated to reflect this specification's change. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * Links to mailing list or IRC discussions * Links to notes from a summit session * Links to relevant research, if appropriate * Related specifications as appropriate (e.g. if it's an EC2 thing, link the EC2 docs) * Anything else you feel it is worthwhile to refer to History ======= Optional section intended to be used each time the spec is updated to describe new design, API or any database schema updated. Useful to let reader understand what's happened along the time. .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Ocata - Introduced

commit_message:
Share get_all_host_states with concurrent requests

This blueprint proposes an optimization to let concurrent request reuse the
return value of "get_all_host_states", so the host manager only need to build
host states once for all the incoming cache-refresh operations during the
building. This optimization can provide the freshest host states as before,
while minimize the database overhead from scheduler service, and accelerate
concurrent cache-refresh operations. It enables filter scheduler to support
much more compute nodes and heavier schedule workload.

Change-Id: I7e76ea526fd9df661e4f3d001b3101d5d9b2a9f1
Blueprint: prune-scheduler-cache-refresh
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/74/345874/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Share "get_all_host_states" with concurrent requests ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/prune-scheduler-cache-refresh The scheduler cache-refresh operation (i.e. the function "get_all_host_states") is very expensive. It needs to build a complete set of host states every time when called by concurrent requests, causing more than 98% overhead in scheduler service [1]_. However, the concurrent processing of "get_all_host_states" are not necessary because they will return (almost) the same results based on the same database queries and host manager caches. This blueprint proposes an optimization to let concurrent request reuse the return value of "get_all_host_states", so the host manager only need to build host states once for all the incoming cache-refresh operations during the building. This optimization can provide the freshest host states as before, while minimize the database overhead from scheduler service, and accelerate concurrent cache-refresh operations. It enables filter scheduler to support much more compute nodes and heavier schedule workload. Problem description =================== From the observations of both simulation (A) and real deployment (B) of very large OpenStack clusters, we identified 3 main problems of filter scheduler: 1. Heavy overhead from cache-refresh, which becomes worse if there're more nodes: * The time cost of cache-refresh from experiment A is *98.5%* when there're 200 ~ 1000 compute nodes and more than 50 concurrent requests. * This cost is *99.7%* from experiment B when there're more than 40 concurrent request and 1000 real compute nodes. * The cache-refresh cost is larger when there're more numbers of compute nodes. The graph [2]_ and [3]_ from experiment A proves it. 2. Longer wait time of cache-refresh if there're more concurrent requests: * Concurrent requests will cause concurrent executions of `get_all_host_states`, result in a much longer waiting for cache-refresh. Experiment A, B (see Figure 1, 2, 3 and 4 in [4]_) prove that the cost is increased with the growth of concurrency. It's only 0.3s when the concurrency is 1, and it is increased to 8s when the concurrency reached 22 at time 34s in Figure 1, 2. * The wait time can even reach 70 seconds, larger than the default `rpc_response_timeout`, causing schedule failures. It happens once in Experiment B, see Figure 5 and 6 in [4]_ for details. * The cache-refresh cost is larger when the request pressure is heavier, see graph [5]_ for their actual relationship. 3. Excessive mysql overhead during cache-refresh operations: * Figure 7 and 8 in [4]_ show the MySQL bytes sent per second reached 30 MBps during scheduling. And the MySQL overhead is not large during the processing in nova-api and nova-compute services. The mentioned two rounds of experiments are: * Experiment A is deployed by devstack. There’re 200 ~ 1000 compute services with fake virt driver. The DB driver is the devstack default PyMySQL. And the scheduler driver is the default filter scheduler. * Experiment B is the real production environment from China Mobile with about 600 active compute nodes. The DB driver is the default driver of SQLAlchemy, i.e. the C based python-mysql. The scheduler is also filter scheduler. The above analysis shows we really need to focus on the cache-refresh bottleneck. It shouldn't have a 99.7% cost in scheduler service, causing scheduler inability to manage more than 1000 compute nodes. Use Cases --------- As a cloud deployer, I really want nova scheduler to manage as many compute nodes as possible. As a cloud user, I don't want to wait too long for instance provisioning in a large and busy cluster. Proposed change =============== We propose to add a transparent layer in `nova.scheduler.host_manager.HostManager.get_all_host_states`, to redirect concurrent cache-refresh requests to one actual operation. The same result will be returned to all the waiting requests. It works in the following scenario: * When the host manager is querying host states for request A, and another request B comes, the host manager won’t launch a second cache-refresh; Instead, it simply reuses the first one and returns the same result to both A and B. In this way, we can reduce the expensive cache-refresh queries to minimum while keeping scheduler host states fresh. And the cache-refresh can become much faster in heavy workload, because concurrent cache-refresh operations will cost much longer time than an individual cache-refresh operation. There is a prototype implementation in [6]_. If we treat scheduler requests as food consumers, and host manager as the food maker, then "food consumers asking food maker for fresh food" and "requests asking host manager for latest host states" are telling the same story: * When there are 5 consumers asking for food, the maker only need to make 1 food instead of 5. Consumers want the food as fresh as possible, so the maker only start to make food when there's a request. Alternatives ------------ Here're some existing solutions for the cache-refresh bottleneck: * Caching scheduler: It executes the real cache-refresh operation periodically, by default 60 seconds. It means recent resource changes in compute nodes may not be available in scheduler, causing inaccurate decisions. And we definitely don't want multiple caching schedulers. * Scheduler filters in DB: It tries to replace cache-refresh and filtering operations from scheduler service to the faster C-based database, by generating SQL queries. But it needs to recalculate the usage information from all the resource-provider resources and their allocations, for every incoming requests, see [7]_. It theoretically introduces more overhead to the centralized scheduler database. * Eventually consistent host states: It requires to add interfaces to nova-scheduler and nova-compute to synchronize scheduler caches from compute nodes to schedulers, and track scheduler claims from schedulers to compute nodes. And it needs a careful implementation to keep caches synchronized. When there're multiple scheduler services, it will introduce more overhead in the message queue. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ TODO Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: cyx1231st <yingxin.cheng@intel.com> Other contributors: None. Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit test required. Reuse the existing functional tests. Documentation Impact ==================== TODO References ========== .. [1] https://www.openstack.org/assets/presentation-media/7129-Dive-into-nova-scheduler-performance-summit.pdf page 15 .. [2] https://www.openstack.org/assets/presentation-media/7129-Dive-into-nova-scheduler-performance-summit.pdf page 9 .. [3] https://www.openstack.org/assets/presentation-media/7129-Dive-into-nova-scheduler-performance-summit.pdf page 11 .. [4] https://docs.google.com/document/d/1N_ZENg-jmFabyE0kLMBgIjBGXfL517QftX3DW7RVCzU/edit?usp=sharing .. [5] https://www.openstack.org/assets/presentation-media/7129-Dive-into-nova-scheduler-performance-summit.pdf page 13 .. [6] https://github.com/cyx1231st/making-food .. [7] https://github.com/jaypipes/placement-bench/blob/master/db.py#L276-L309

subject: Move Cinder admin tests into unversioned path
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-27 18:40:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/cbe4ef6d12481a96ae443b4430da446eac9c004f', 'message': 'Move Cinder admin tests into unversioned path

As http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/114507.html
we will use the existing Cinder V2 API tests for testing the base
microversion of Cinder V3 API also.
So it is not necessary to contain versioned path in test module pathes.

commit_message:
Move Cinder admin tests into unversioned path

As http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/114507.html
we will use the existing Cinder V2 API tests for testing the base
microversion of Cinder V3 API also.
So it is not necessary to contain versioned path in test module pathes.
This patch just moves Cinder admin tests to unversioned pathes.

Change-Id: I2acfe5a28a2533b16565e6ebad5c820e7c3a3967

commit_message:
Migrate action support destination host

This describes migrate server with specify destination host.

Change-Id: I546870b6ecf8aa5b0b63a8320357c02c7c92ffd1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/58/331558/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Migrate action support destination host ========================================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/migrate-action-support-destination-host In live migrations, we can assign the target host to migrate. But, it cannot assign the target host for migration in cold migrations. Sometimes, it needs migrate vms with target host. This spec proposes adding optional arguments host for cold migration with target host in migrate API. Problem description =================== As an administrator, In order to maintain my system, I want to migrate virtual machine to the given host. I can use live-migration and assign the destination host, but sometimes, when I maintain the system, some VMs are stopped by their users, I must use cold migration to move them. Currently nova cold migration can not specify the destination host for the virtual machine where the migration results for the administrator is unknown. Use Cases ---------- * As an operator of an OpenStack cloud, I expect cold migration can specify the target host, so virtual machines can be migrated to the host I expected, but not other hosts. Proposed change =============== Extend migrate API. Some new fields will be added in conductor and migrate API. Adding an optional parameter host, the default is None, then the host passed conductor, if the host is None, select the host by the scheduler; if the host is not None, then check the host service is normal, hypervisor matches, enough memory If satisfied, send the message to the host for migration. New API arguments: * host: the destination host name. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- The `nova.api.openstack.compute.migrate_server` _migrate body would have 1 new arguments. For the migrate-server.json and request body, the following constructs would suffice :: request:json { "migrate": { "host": "", } } REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: DeSheng Yin<yin.desheng@zte.com.cn> Work Items ---------- * Add Optional arguments host in migrate request. * If host is not None, Conductor need check the host. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittest and funtional tests in Nova Documentation Impact ==================== Doc the API change in the API Reference: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html References ========== migrate-v2.1: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#migrate-v2.1 History ======= None

commit_message:
Use stevedore for plugin config of block device

This patch introduces stevedore plugin mechanism for use
with the block device layer.  This makes it possible that
other projects pass in their own block device plugins.

Change-Id: Id3ea56aaf75f5a20a4e1b6ac2a68adb12c56b574
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

commit_message:
API support for image signing

This spec describes a change to the "show" method
of the compute service API. If Nova verified the
signature of an instance's disk image prior to boot,
information about the certificate chain used to
verify the signature will be stored by Nova and
included in the "show" response.

Change-Id: I23b6eeef2e00042ca605e04cf5a97b79c9a5cc97
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/89/323389/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ API Support for Image Signature Verification ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/nova-support-image-signing As of Mitaka, Nova is capable of verifying digital signatures associated with Glance images. For more information on this work, view the original spec [2]. When signature verification for Glance images is enabled, the certificate used to create the image's signatures must be verified against a root certificate that is trusted by the compute service. The change described in this document alters the Nova API so that it exposes the certificate chain of trust to the end user. When signature verification is performed prior to boot, Nova will store data about the signing certificate, the trusted root certificate, and any intermediate certificates. The response to "show" API requests will include this data for each instance if it is present. Problem description =================== VM images are high-value targets to an adversary in a cloud environment because an adversary gains a persistent foothold and access to all projects that use the compromised image. In effect, a single compromised VM image becomes a common source of malware infection across a cloud. Such a scenario undermines trust in the cloud and the cloud provider. We want to provide an automated capability whereby unauthorized changes to a VM image are detected by the cloud provider and the end user may verify the authenticity of the image via secure cryptographic operations. As of the Kilo release, OpenStack's protection against the unauthorized modification of images was limited to verifying an MD5 checksum. While protecting against accidental modifications, MD5 is a hash function, not an authentication primitive, and thus provides no protection against deliberate, malicious modification of images. Such modifications could occur in transit, such as when the image is uploaded to Glance or transferred to Nova, or at rest, either when the image is stored in Glance or cached by a compute host. Moreover, any hash of the image (regardless of the hash algorithm) could be replaced by an adversary, which severely limits the ability to detect unauthorized modifications to the image. Signature verification allows Nova to verify the signature before booting and to alert the end user of modifications. We want the end user to be able to verify that the cloud provider is booting the desired VM image; which means that the end user must be able to be verify that image signature verification is performed, and that the signing certificate is trusted. As it is currently implemented, the signature verification workflow provides no method by which the end user can determine that the signing certificate and the root certificate against which it is verified are trusted. This leaves the end user vulnerable to attacks in which an adversary replaces a valid signed image with another signed image. By checking the certificate chain, the end user would be able to determine that the disk image was signed by a user that they trust. Use Cases --------- The end user wants to create an instance from a signed image, and be able to detect any of the following attacks: * An adversary replaces the desired image with another signed image * An adversary alters the desired image and the signature metadata Since the Nova API will display the signing certificate chain, the end user will be able to mitigate these attacks by checking that the image was signed by the expected entity. This feature supports the case where the end user requires detailed information about the entity which signed an image which they are booting. This change proposes that, whenever Nova performs Glance image signature verification prior to creating a server, Nova will store the certificate chain of trust which was used to validate the image's signing certificate. The response to the "show" request will be amended to include this data. This change paves the way for better integration of signature verification into the Horizon interface. Since the Nova API returns the data of all certificates in the chain, this information can be displayed in Horizon. With this information, the end user can verify the integrity of their disk image much like the user of a browser can check the integrity of their TLS connection. Proposed change =============== The certificate validation functionality amends the download method of Nova's image service client to return the certificate chain of trust in addition to the image data whenever image signature verification occurs. The proposed change adds the certificate chain to the Instance object as a list variable with the name "signing_certificate_chain". The Nova API populates the response to the show request with this certificate chain. The "signing_certificate_chain" field is a list of structures, each of which contains the distinguished name, the public key algorithm and size, and the base64 encoding of a certificate in the chain. RFC 5280 specifies the distinguished name as composed of the fields "country", "organization", "organizational_unit", "state_or_province_name", "common_name", and "serial_number" [1]. The public key algorithm and size will be listed as the fields "algorithm" and "key_size". The "algorithm" field will be one of "RSA", "ECC", or "DSA" and the "key_size" field will be specified in bits. The "signing_certificate_chain" list begins with the certificate used to sign the image and ends with the certificate of the trusted root CA. This chain typically contains a maximum of four certificates. When signature verification does not occur, the image service client will return an empty list as the certificate chain. This empty list will be added to the Instance as the "signing_certificate_chain" and returned by the API in response to a show request. Alternatives ------------ The alternative is to provide no information about the signing and root certificates. This leaves the end user with no means to verify that the image is signed by a certificate owned by a trusted entity, and that the signing certificate has been validated against a trusted CA. The deployment may trust a larger set of root CAs than an end user trusts, so merely verifying an image's signature and validating the signing certificate may be insufficient to meet the end user's requirements. Data model impact ----------------- This change adds a "signing_certificate_chain" field to the Instance object. REST API impact --------------- An example response to a show request, i.e. a response to a GET request to /v2.1/​{tenant_id}​/servers/​{server_id}​ is as follows if image signature verification has occurred: :: { "server": { "addresses": { "private": [ { "addr": "192.168.0.3", "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr": "aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff", "OS-EXT-IPS:type": "fixed", "version": 4 } ] }, "created": "2013-09-23T13:37:00Z", "flavor": { "id": "1", "links": [ { "href": "http://openstack.example.com/openstack/flavors/1", "rel": "bookmark" } ] }, "hostId": "9cc36101a27c2a69c1a18241f6228454d9d7f466bd90c62db8e8b856", "id": "f474386b-4fb6-4e1f-b1d5-d6bf4437f7d5", "image": { "id": "70a599e0-31e7-49b7-b260-868f441e862b", "links": [ { "href": "b8b357f7100d4391828f2177c922ef93", "OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:hypervisor_hostname": "fake-mini", "OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:instance_name": "instance-00000001", "OS-EXT-STS:power_state": 1, "OS-EXT-STS:task_state": null, "OS-EXT-STS:vm_state": "active", "os-extended-volumes:volumes_attached": [], "OS-SRV-USG:launched_at": "2013-09-23T13:37:00.880302", "OS-SRV-USG:terminated_at": null, "progress": 0, "security_groups": [ { "name": "default" } ], "status": "ACTIVE", "host_status": "UP", "tenant_id": "openstack", "updated": "2013-10-31T07:31:30Z", "user_id": "fake" } } If signature verification does not occur, the "signing_certificate_chain" field will contain an empty list. Security impact --------------- This change increases the usability of the signature verification feature by giving the end user the ability to easily check whether their image was signed by an unexpected certificate. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: dane-fichter Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): Not Yet Identified Work Items ---------- * Amend the Instance object to include the "signing_certificate_chain" field. Parse and add this chain to the Instance when signature verification occurs. * Amend the response to the show request to include the certificate chain's data. Dependencies ============ * Implementation of certificate validation functionality [2], [3] Testing ======= Functional tests will be added to validate the response to the boot request. Documentation Impact ==================== The API reference needs to be updated. References ========== [1] https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc5280.txt [2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/approved/image-verification.html [3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/314718/
